<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module4_mcq_q69')" data-correct-answer="C">
  <strong style="display: block;">
  An analyst estimates a firm’s cost of equity using CAPM with β=1.2, but she mistakenly uses the short-term T-bill rate (1%) as the risk-free rate,  even though the project horizon is 10 years. What is the main issue with this approach?
  </strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q69" value="A"> A. The market risk premium already accounts for horizon differences, so no error occurs.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q69" value="B"> B. Short-term T-bills are always preferable as risk-free rates in CAPM.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q69" value="C"> C. The risk-free rate should match the project’s horizon; using a short-term rate understates the true cost of equity.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q69" value="D"> D. CAPM does not require a risk-free rate, so the choice is irrelevant.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q69" value="E"> E. The beta will automatically adjust if the wrong risk-free rate is used.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_mcq_q69" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C. In CAPM, the risk-free rate must correspond to the horizon of the project or asset being valued. Using a short-term T-bill for a long-term project underestimates the required return, biasing the cost of equity downward.
</div>

:::
